courses.name: Biochemistry I: Proteins, Lipids and Metabolism

cmCourseInfo.description: Proteins, enzymes, membranes and the metabolism of carbohydrates and lipids. This course is intended for students who are NOT taking BCH242Y1 as part of their program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biochemistry I: Proteins, Lipids and Metabolism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Successful completion of (CHM135H1, CHM136H1)/CHM151Y1  NOTE: CHM1** with COURSE EXCLUSION TO CHM135H1 AND CHM136H1 meet the Prerequisite requirement for BCH210H1. CHM110H5 & CHM120H5 (UTM) are equivalent to CHM135H1 ONLY. CHMA10H3 & CHMA11H3 (UTSC) are equivalent to CHM135H1 ONLY. CHMB41H3/CHMB42H3 (UTSC) are equivalent to CHM136H1 ONLY.  CHM242H5 (UTM) is equivalent to CHM136H1 ONLY. Students with a SDF in CHM135H1/CHM136H1 are not permitted to enrol in BCH210H1 until a final passing grade (50%) appears on the transcript.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: BCH242Y1, [CHM361H5(UTM) and CHM362H5(UTM)], [BIOC12H3(UTSC) and BIOC13H3(UTSC)], CHMB62H3(UTSC)

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online - Asynchronous: Lectures will be delivered asynchronously online. 10% of the assessments will be for tutorial participation, which will be delivered synchronously online and recorded for later asynchronous viewing; 65% of the assessments will be "take-home" assessments submitted at various way points throughout the course. 25% of the assessments will take the form of online questions and quizzes that will be completed on a weekly basis throughout the term. Students need access to Quercus and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate. The detailed course schedule and assessment breakdown will be provided on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course that will serve as the foundation for BCH courses taken in Third and Fourth years by students specializing in biochemistry and related specialist programs. The major topics include protein structure, enzyme mechanisms, cellular and molecular biology, lipid and membrane structure and function, and carbohydrate, lipid, and amino acid metabolism and bioenergetics. Please note that there are five laboratories accompanying this course. (Lab fees:$10)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Biochemistry
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: BCH210H1 and BCH311H1,  [CHM361H5(UTM) and CHM362H5(UTM)], [BIOC12H3 (UTSC) and BIOC13H3 (UTSC)], CHMB62H3(UTSC)

Students need access to Quercus and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

courses.name: Biochemistry II: Nucleic Acids and Biological Information Flow

cmCourseInfo.description: Nucleic acids and flow of information in biological systems. Information storage and transmission by nucleic acids, as well as new molecular technologies will be discussed. Registration in one of the tutorial sessions is mandatory. Note: Students that have a SDF in BCH210H1 are not permitted to enrol in BCH311H1 until a final passing grade (50%) appears on the transcript. BCH2** WITH COURSE EXCLUSION TO BCH210H1 meets the prerequisite requirement for BCH311H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biochemistry II: Nucleic Acids and Biological Information Flow

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be given as online videos delivered asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online tutorials (Thursdays 1 pm-2 pm; Friday 1 pm-2 pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Students should have the ability to use Quercus, Blackboard Collaborate, and Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: Proteins are the main functional units in the cell and are part of almost every biochemical process. They catalyze many metabolic reactions and also play central roles in signaling pathways. Some proteins have crucial structural and mechanical functions. In this course, a detailed overview of protein structure, stability, folding, and protein-ligand interactions will be given with strong emphasis on discussing the basic principles in the field. Biophysical, theoretical, and proteomic methods used to study protein stability and folding and protein-ligand interactions will be presented. Protein misfolding diseases will also be discussed. The course will offer a solid basis in protein biochemistry. It is recommended for those interested in pursuing graduate studies or professional degrees in health or medicine.
cmCourseInfo.title: Proteins: from Structure to Proteomics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For more information on how to enrol, please send an email, with your student# ID, to jennifer.haughton@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Course material will be delivered online in a mixture of synchronous and asynchronous formats. All formal lectures will be recorded for asynchronous consumption. Students must be available from 1:00-2:00PM on M/W/F for synchronous course activities including occasional assessments (term tests, quizzes, etc).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to provide hands-on experience at an introductory level, employing a variety of biochemical techniques commonly used in research and clinical diagnostic laboratories. This course is intended for students who are not proceeding further in biochemistry. It is highly recommended that students take this course in their third year as space is limited and priority will go to third-year students. This course will be offered in the FALL & WINTER terms. Attendance in the first week of class is mandatory in order to receive safety information and laboratory protocols. (Enrolment limited.) (Lab fees: $50)
cmCourseInfo.title: Laboratory Course in Biochemical Techniques

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Eligible students must enroll via ACORN. Students who are not eligible, please send an email, with your student #, to jennifer.haughton@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Dual Delivery Flipped Classroom model: Pre-lab material is presented online asynchronously. In-person labs will be held if possible following institutional and public health guidance for physical distancing. Access to Quercus is required. In-person labs will be modified to accommodate for physical distancing and other measures; as such, students will be required to sign up for a two hour lab time slot in Quercus. Students must also be available for the entire class time as some classes will be delivered online synchronously. The detailed course schedule will be provided on Quercus.

Delivery Instructions

Pre-lab material is presented online asynchronously. Access to Quercus and Zoom is required. In-person sections: In-person labs will be held if possible following institutional and public health guidelines including physical distancing and other measures; in-person labs will run from 9-11 am. Online sections: Online synchronous lab sessions will run from 11:30 am to 1 pm.  Students in all sections (online and in-person) must be available for the entire class time (9 am - 1 pm), as some classes will be delivered online synchronously for all students. The detailed course schedule will be provided on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to fundamental laboratory techniques in modern biochemistry. Experiments illustrate and develop the concepts described in lecture courses and serve as a foundation for more advanced training in biochemistry laboratory courses. Enrollment in this course is generally restricted to students enrolled in the Biochemistry, Immunology, and Molecular Genetics & Microbiology (Genetics Stream) Specialist programs. (Lab fees: $25)

Enrollment in this course is generally restricted to students enrolled in the Biochemistry Specialist program.

cmCourseInfo.description: Structural features of membrane proteins, their biogenesis and methods of analysis. Function of membrane proteins as transporters, channels, pumps and receptors. Molecular aspects of disease processes linked to membrane proteins.
cmCourseInfo.title: Membrane Proteins: Structure, and Function

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Eligible students must enroll via ACORN. Students who are not eligible, please send an email, with your student# ID, to jennifer.haughton@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Dual Delivery, HyFlex model: Lectures will be delivered online asynchronous. Tutorials will be synchronous and held on Thursdays from 11 am -12 noon as per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be streamed online and may be offered in-person if possible, following public health guidance.  Synchronous assessments (term tests) will also occur at this time, so students must be available from 11 am -12 noon on Thursdays throughout the term. Access to Quercus is required.

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory of modern biophysical techniques as applied to the study of the structure and function of macromolecules; emphasis on X-ray crystallography, electron cryomicroscopy, NMR spectroscopy, and other spectroscopic methods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Structural Biology: Principles and Practice
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BCH210H1/BCH242Y1. This is a problem-solving course and will require use of skills from introductory physics, math, and/or chemistry courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online – Synchronous: Lectures will be delivered online in a synchronous format, as will office hours and class discussions. Assessments will consist of take-home assignments/problem sets and online term tests. Students need access to Quercus, and the ability to attend videoconferences during lecture hours.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is focussed on the molecular aspects of signal transduction, covering how cells receive and then transmit signals via intracellular proteins such as kinases and phosphatases and how this ultimately regulates cell function. Specific topics covered may include calcium regulation and signalling by extracellular ligands including morphogens, growth factors and/or insulin.
cmCourseInfo.title: Regulation of Signalling Pathways

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

Course material will be delivered online in a synchronous format, as will office hours and class discussions. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Genomics of Microbial Communities in Human Health and Beyond

cmCourseInfo.description: There is a growing appreciation that microbes do not operate in isolation but form parts of larger populations and communities (microbiomes) with unique considerations for human health. Combining lectures, small group discussions, and a computer lab component, this course will cover how genomics can be applied to analyze microbial communities and the transformative discoveries that continue to result.
cmCourseInfo.title: Genomics of Microbial Communities in Human Health and Beyond

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This lecture course has a mandatory laboratory component which will occur on specific lecture days. The laboratory schedule will be assigned in the first week of classes. Eligible students must enroll via ACORN during the priority period. Students who are not eligible, please send an email, with your student ID number, to jennifer.haughton@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Course material will be delivered online in a mixture of synchronous and asynchronous formats. All formal lectures will be recorded for asynchronous consumption. Students must be available from 10:00-11:00 on Wednesdays for synchronous online tutorials (approximately biweekly) and occasional assessments (term tests, quizzes on assigned readings). Computer labs will be run asynchronously and make use of Geneious or similar software (limited-use licenses will be provided free of charge). Students' computers will need to meet the minimum requirements as outlined in the syllabus and at www.geneious.com.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: January 11, 2021: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Protein homeostasis is dependent on the coordinated synthesis, folding, localization and degradation of the thousands of proteins in a living cell. This course deals with selected aspects of the process including: 1) mRNA synthesis, 2) ribosome structure and function, 3) translation initiation, elongation and termination, 4) protein folding and the role of chaperones, 5) protein degradation via the ubiquitin proteasome system and 6) protein aging and disease. The course will serve as a foundation for those with an interest in how cellular protein levels and conformations are maintained.
cmCourseInfo.title: Protein Homeostasis

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Eligible students must enroll via ACORN. Students who are not eligible, please send an email with your student# ID, to jennifer.haughton@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

The course lectures will be presented in online-synchronous format.  Recordings of the lectures will be made available.  Students should have a computer with microphone and camera so that they can participate in class discussions.

cmCourseInfo.description:
This course is an introduction to computational methods and internet resources in modern biochemistry and molecular biology. The main topics include: sequence and genome databases, sequence alignment and homology search, use and interpretation of molecular structure, and phylogenetic analysis. Assignments focus on hands-on competence building with web-based bioinformatics tools and databases, downloadable software including a molecular viewer and a multiple sequence alignment editor, and the statistics workbench and programming language “R”. For syllabus details see: www.biochemistry.utoronto.ca/undergraduates/courses/BCH441H/

Note BCB420H1 extends this syllabus to computational topics of systems biology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Bioinformatics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BCH210H1/BCH242Y1; BCH311H1/MGY311Y1/PSL350H1 or special permission of the course coordinator

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online in an asychronous format (with optional streaming available on Tuesdays from 17:00-18:30). Office hours will be offered flexible, on demand, using Videoconferencing software. Computer labs will use the R programming language and the R Studioe IDE (free).Minimum computer requirements are minimal.

courses.name: Organelles in Cell Function and Death

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced principles and concepts of cell biology are covered including the structure, biogenesis, and dynamic behavior of cell organelles. The specific contributions to the life and death of the cell are highlighted. Signaling events that integrate cellular communication are discussed. Specifically, the interplay between the Endoplasmic Reticulum, Peroxisomes and Mitochondria is highlighted. Mitochondrial biogenesis and membrane dynamics as they relate to apoptosis and cellular signaling/integration are presented as they relate to human disease. State-of-the-art imaging techniques and the contributions of cell biology to modern day advances in medicine are also presented.
cmCourseInfo.title: Organelles in Cell Function and Death

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note

Delivery Instructions

Course material will be delivered online in a synchronous format, as will office hours and class discussions. Lectures and class discussions will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Structure and Function of the Nucleus

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the structure and function of the cell nucleus and the genome through the lens of biochemistry, molecular biology, cell biology and evolution. A focus is placed on the major scientific developments that shaped our current understanding. Topics that will be covered are eukaryogenesis, junk DNA, the structure of DNA and chromatin, the transfer of information between genotype and phenotype, the filtering of information found in the genome into biologically relevant molecules such as mRNA, the processing and export of these products from the nucleus into the cytoplasm, and the translation of mRNA into protein. We will also investigate how various organelles, such as the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria, played a role in the evolution of the nucleus. Finally we will investigate how biological information is partitioned during mitosis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Structure and Function of the Nucleus

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will apply core biochemical principles to explain the pathogenesis of emerging diseases at the molecular level and describe advanced biochemical technologies used to understand and treat these illnesses. Students will be exposed to how biochemical principles influence medical diagnoses, therapy and the development of new drugs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medical Biochemistry

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will cover the action of the biochemical targets of the existing antibiotics (nucleotide-, RNA-, DNA-, protein- and cell wall synthesis, the manner in which these pathways are inhibited in antimicrobial therapy and the biochemical basis of antibiotic resistance. The biochemistry and origin of naturally occurring and synthetic antibiotics will be introduced. (Enrolment limited.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Antibiotics and Antibiotic Targets

cmCourseInfo.description: Experiments extend students’ technical abilities as well as their knowledge and application of practical theory. This course is designed as an advanced successor in a progression of biochemistry laboratory experiences in BCH242Y1, BCH377H1 and BCH378H1 that will equip students with a spectrum of practical abilities that are of vital importance in scientific research. (Lab fees: $25)
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Dual Delivery, Flipped Classroom model: Weekly lectures will be posted online in an asynchronous format. In-person labs will be held if possible following institutional and public health guidance for physical distancing. Videos of core lab methodologies and utilization of existing datasets will be used to deliver the course for those wishing to complete the material online. Access to Quercus is required.

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar course will foster close interactions between students and Faculty and encourage in depth discussion not only of results but the ways the results were presented and the rationales for experimental design. Critical thinking skills will be developed, as will presentation skills, as students become presenters of results and take on the role of scientist presenting and analyzing new findings. Writing skills will be developed through an essay assignment. Students within the audience will also have access to the experimental papers and be encouraged to pose thoughtful questions about research and the ways that research can be communicated within the scientific community. Thus the new seminar course will foster an appreciation of scientific writing and give students a venue to develop their communication skills. The goal of the seminar course is to improve both the written and oral scientific communication skills of our Specialist students, as well as to increase their knowledge of key papers in Biochemistry.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Seminar in Biochemistry

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment
